body: LGTM

What scheduler are you using? If it's Quartz then it seems like there is an annotation to disallow concurrent executions: http://quartz-scheduler.org/api/2.2.0/org/quartz/DisallowConcurrentExecution.html

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2676295/quartz-preventing-concurrent-instances-of-a-job-in-jobs-xml
Is option 2 `${PORT_?1234}` needed? I just don't want us to create too many options for specifying the port. For option 3 `${PORT_1234+}` may be more intuitive than `${PORT_1234?}`

@sahilTakiar I'm using Quartz, but I don't think the disallow concurrent execution annotation will work.  It is stated in at least one comment that the jobs get queued.

Either way, I removed the code for the job.lock.denied.behavior..

@chavdar why are tests added to TestNG restricted to unit tests?
- The current store implementations only require working with a `FileSystem` I'm not sure why we can't use the `SimpleLocalHDFSConfigStoreFactory` for this
- We do have the ability to setup HDFS clusters using the [MiniClusters](https://wiki.apache.org/hadoop/HowToDevelopUnitTests), `GobblinYarnAppLauncherTest` is already doing this
  - This should also allow us to spawn multiple clusters, I'm not sure why these integration tests need that though
  - I've used `MiniDFSCluster` before and it works well
- Getting this to run via TestNG also ensures the tests get run on each build
  - Correct me if I am wrong but we currently have to run the integration tests on Azkaban manually; and even if we did automate runs on Azkaban that would only happen internally

Whats the reason for removing the `rollback` method? The problem with just having a `deploy` method is that now deployed version are basically mutable.

The advantage of the rollback method is that it shouldn't need to modify any files, it just changes the symlink file.

A version is NOT mutable. Take a look at line 436 in the `deploy` method, we copy a new set of files from classpath only if the version does not exist on HDFS. For instance when we rollback from 0.7 to 0.3 no new configs will be copied to 0.3 directory even if the files have changed in classpath. We only update the metadata file to 0.3
Ok thats fine, but still whats the reason for not having a `rollback` method that just sets the version.

We do not have the need for that now. Let us add the `rollback` interface when such a requirement comes up.
From the `StoreDeployer` I always call the deploy method with the version to be deployed. It can either be an existing version (a rollback) or a new version.

I'm confused, I thought the point of this PR was to add rollback functionality as stated in the PR description "Removed rollback for Deployable interface as the deploy will be used for rollback as well"

My question is whats the justification for using the `deploy` method for rollbacks instead of having an explicit `rollback` method? The `rollback` method shouldn't be particularly complex as you already have the work to update the symlink file. I think having a `rollback` method makes more sense than using the `deploy` method for rollbacks, at least from a usability perspective.
@sahilTakiar Updated. Moved the test classes to src/test and fixed the depenencies

Hi @sahilTakiar 
If we have separate methods `rollback` and `deploy` the user has to pass from command line or in the azkaban props the operation he is trying to do. Then the `StoreDeployer` needs to have logic to decide whether to call `SimpleHDFSStore.deploy` or `SimpleHDFSStore.rollback`.
With the way I have it, the user does not have to specify the operation from command line and `StoreDeployer` always calls `SimpleHDFSStore.deploy`
We can discuss offline if you still have concerns.

Can rollbacks just be done from the command line? If its Azkaban there can be a separate job for rollbacks.

We can discuss more on Monday.

Hey @marcelstoer thanks a bunch! Will definitely take a look at what you have done. Thanks for mentioning the other two issues too. I have updated the PR description to make the summary more complete.

@sahilTakiar Is there a way to preview the rendered markdown before merging?

@ibuenros you mean view what the documentation would like on ReadTheDocs? All of these files are checked into a branch called `readTheDocs`. ReadTheDocs lets you specify what branch the docs are in, so there is already a page with all the rendered docs: http://gobblin.readthedocs.org/en/readthedocs/
What I mean is, in the future, if I am adding a new page, is it possible to see the rendering by mkdocs before merging with master?
LGTM
Can you add javadoc and copyright block to all classes?
Other than javadoc, this looks good to me. @sahilTakiar any other comments?

@ibuenros There is one issue.  The problem is that the app_master determines the ports, but I think it needs to keep track "globally" of what it has assigned and these ports need to be released later.  That way if the app_master spins up more containers it won't try to reuse them.  This problem is particularly problematic because if the port is already used it can keep a container from starting.

ah I see, yes its definitely possible. I will work on adding some documentation on how to do this. You essentially need to:
- Install MkDocs locally
  - This is pretty easy assuming you have `pip` installed, its just `pip install mkdocs`
- `cd` to the top level dir of Gobblin and run `mkdocs serve`
  - This starts a local server that serves documentation so you can go to a URL and see what it looks like
  - Its pretty nice because any local changes to documentation made while the server is running will cause MkDocs to re-render the modified pages automatically
Sweet!!!!!!  Now it would be create to get checkstyle enforcement baked into the travis build.

LGTM
- Had some offline discussion about whether to include the `rollback` feature - sticking to current approach for now to unblock this PR, and will discuss with @chavdar offline

Looks like there may be some problems with this, seems Travis is killing the builds because they are taking up too many resources. My guess is that the addition of the `jacoco` plugin is causing this. Will see if I can decrease the number of threads used.
@ydai1124 updated d1eddb9

It seems setting `org.gradle.parallel` to `false` helps out. So I am disabling this property from Travis builds only. The build takes a little longer, but I think that should be ok since we want to increase the reliability of Travis builds.

@ibuenros Updated based on your comments.  
1. Removed a bunch of overrides for `TaskSchedulerFactory`, and added one that takes the enum rather than the string.  
2. Made the `TaskSchedulerType` enum public.  
3. Indicated that `TaskScheduler` implementations should be thread-safe. 
4. Added javadocs for all non-test classes and method (even private and package visibility). 
5. Fail the `schedule` call if the task cannot be scheduler

Are we going to use this feature when launching the App Master? It seems to be only added for launching containers?

One more question, the code currently checks for available ports in the app master, but just because a port is available on the app master doesn't mean it will be available in a new container, right?

@sahilTakiar Don't merge this yet.  We need some way to ensure that the ports are taken/release on a node basis. The way that things are working right now with spinning up the containers, doesn't make it easy to "reserve" ports.  While the app_master could do the book keeping to ensure that containers it spins up are only picking ports not used by other containers, it is not able to test that the ports are available.  Additionally, if the port is not available, the container will fail to start.  Yes, I think we would want a similar functionality on the app_master because it is on a shared resource as well.

As an alternative, we could just support programmatically enabling the JMX server (I know I've seen how to do this, but I can't find it now).  That would cover my main scenario.  YourKit can be attached to a running JVM as well (not programmatically at the moment, but it is possible).
LGTM
@sahilTakiar I'm running this locally and so far the issues seem to be fixed.  I still have metrics and jmx disabled, but I'll try it with them enabled later today.
@kadaan awesome! good to know. I will work on rebasing this PR and addressing your comments sometime today.

High level structure:
1. RegressionTest is the entry point of the test
2. Based on the configuration, ExpectedResultBuilder will build all the expected results by parsing the json file "expected.conf" for each node
3. There are multiple levels of validation
   A. validate through SimpleHDFSConfigStore
   B. validate through the InMemoryTopology and InMemoryValueInspector
   C. validate through the ConfigClient
